message:
جوجل ويوداسيتي أعلنوا عن ٢٠٠٠ منحة للمصريين في برنامج Android Nanodegree وأيضا فعاليات توظيف للخريجين منها.

انا حاليا مسجلة لبرنامج Front End Nanodegree والبرنامج جدا رائع وأنصح جدا بالتسجيل لبرنامج الأندرويد خصوصا أن المساقات تم انتاجها بمساعدة جوجل ويتم الان تعريبها وتوفير ترجمة بالعربية.

ملاحظة: البرنامج ليس للمبتدئيين. يجب أن يكون عندك خلفية في البرمجة.
story: Rasha Rasem Khatib shared a link to the group: Egyptian Geeks.
name: Introducing the Android Developer Nanodegree - Udacity - Climb Higher
caption: blog.udacity.com
description: The industry's first Android Developer Nanodegree is built by Google's subject matter experts to the standards they expect of Android developers.

data.message: احتمال كبير اسجل بكرة .. هو مبلغ وقدره بس الموضوع مغري
اللي ما باخد منحة وبدفع و بخلص البرنامج كله برجعوله نص المبلغ
برنامج ايه يعنى ؟ !
200 $ per month for 9 months ?

Fakaah ya 3anii :D :D :D
Mot2akden enga men7a :D loooool
You can finish it in less time. Also as I said, whenever you finish it you get half the money back, that's of course if you don't get the scholarship.
how to apply to the scholarship??

I am not sure, but you can post your question on the udacity facebook page or email them to ask. I am just posting what I learned at Google I/O I don't know much details. I am already a student on udacity and won a scholarship on their website.

Can you tell us more about "Front End Nanodegree"?
I'm a front-end developer it might be good for me.
Thanks in advance :)

It's a pretty cool program that I am enjoying very much, they focus a lot on giving you skills that are good for the market so you have to finish some tasks related to your resume and add the projects that you did so far and keep your profile updated. They have a timeline with projects that are asked form you, they also give you recommended classes to attend in order to finish the project, even though I already worked with fron end technologies I watched even the introductory classes about stuff I already know, because they have awesome developers that already have jobs as front end developer and who would give you a lot of advices on how you should write your code and how to start with a task, and all these small things that make a difference in the code you write.

They let you use github extensively to have all your projects there so recruiters can take a look when/if you apply for a job and see that you indeed know what you're talking abotu and actually worked with it. 

Projects cover, HTML, CSS, Javascript, HTML5 Canvas, Object Oriented Javascript, Website optimization, using APIs like maps, and Javascript testing. 

You get feedback for every project you submit. My last project included feedback about good things I've done, and feedback on small things I should fix, like a missing semicolon, adding other browsers support for animation, removing an empty function that I forgot about, and some missing html closing tag. This was the thing I built, which is an online resume I customized for something they provided us with, as I am following up with Intro to Javascript course:
http://rashahussein.github.io/online-resume/

And this is the code: https://github.com/RashaHussein/online-resume

Thank you for the information.
Very interesting work, Good for you :)
I think i have a pretty good experience in those techniques.
But if i may ask, who's responsible for this program?

Udacity and Google are behind it. This project was pretty basic for me, I already had an online resume, but built it anyway, because I wanted feedback on my code structure and I am more conscious to building well organized code this way. They gave me good feedback on the modularity of my code which I never had in the online resume that I built on my own, the code was all over the place (www.rasha.me) ! I kinda also learned more about how to build your own templating system, which I never thought about. i mean I know how templating works but never thought of building my own and how would that be like.
They ask that you have prior experience in the topics listed, but of course if you already have extensive experience in them, then no need to take it. It's not a zero to hero program, it's to enhance your already existing skills. The main thing about it is you building the projects, and following up with the career program they have setup for you, including hangouts with udacity people. You can skip the classes if you think you know what's in there. however I didn't skip any class, i think I am a big fan of those guys! I also always have something to learn, I usually watch the classes on a 2X speed though, cause most of the info in the intro classes was stuff I know. However the classes on mobile web, responsive design, responsive images and optimization, were full of good stuff and good practices I didn't know about. 

The next project is an Arcade Game. This one is supposed to be challenging. 

The guy who founded udacity is the same one who founded Google X. And he wants to revolutionize education! They're adding more nanodegrees. I might consider getting into the mobile world sometime later.

Sounds cool :)
However i prefer the online materials and documentations to learn any new technology. Books also is so great method to learn.
I think courses might be waste of time but looks like you found it useful for you.
wish you best of luck :D
By the way if you interested in JS i write some articles about it here you might like Geeky Quizzes

Yeah I do read book, articles, I contribute to open source (www.manshar.com) but I love their courses and I find them very helpful and resourceful. I love their engineers and hearing about their experience. What I love the most is frequent quizzes and when the one who gives the course has built something cool, like the Web Development course, it was given by the cofounder of reddit, and I used their hotness algorithm for listing popular articles on Manshar - منشر .

I knew Manshar of course, I've read your articles about the interviews in Google and Facebook ...etc.
Very interesting work keep going (y)
Thank You :-)
كان نفسي يعملوا منحة لبرنامج الـ full stack developer

Google is very interested in android and looking to hire more android devs. 
Also If you look at their job postings you will almost never find full stack positions, you're either a front end, a back end or a software engineer.
Moha Misho
Ahmed Roshdi
I just wanna know what are the skills should i have to be qualified to get this scholarship with google
I believe in order to take it you have to know a little but of java. But I would say just apply with passion and let them know how much you want it and how much you're excited about it!
Requirements are on the course page https://www.udacity.com/course/android-developer-nanodegree--nd801
